verses.text: \sc Now\sc* it came to pass in the days when the judges ruled, that there was a famine in the land. And a \add certain\add* man of Beth-lehem-judah went to sojourn in the country of Moab, he, and his wife, and his two sons.

And the name of the man \add was\add* Elimelech, and the name of his wife Naomi, and the name of his two sons Mahlon and Chilion, Ephrathites of Beth-lehem-judah. And they came \add into\add* the country of Moab, and continued there.
And Elimelech Naomi’s husband died; and she was left, and her two sons.
And they took them wives of the women of Moab; the name of the one \add was\add* Orpah, and the name of the other Ruth: and they dwelled there about ten years.
And Mahlon and Chilion died also both of them; and the woman was left of her two sons and her husband.

Then she arose with her daughters in law, that she might return from the country of Moab: for she had heard in the country of Moab how that the \sc Lord\sc* had visited his people in giving them bread.
Wherefore she went forth out of the place where she was, and her two daughters in law with her; and they went on the way to return unto the land of Judah.
And Naomi said unto her two daughters in law, Go, return each to her mother’s house: the \sc Lord\sc* deal kindly with you, as ye have dealt with the dead, and with me.
The \sc Lord\sc* grant you that you may find rest, each \add of you in\add* the house of her husband. Then she kissed them; and they lift up their voice, and wept.
And they said unto her, Surely we will return with thee unto thy people.
And Naomi said, Turn again, my daughters: why will you go with me? \add are there\add* yet \add any more\add* sons in my womb, that they may be your husbands?
Turn again, my daughters, go \add your way;\add* for I am too old to have a husband. If I should say, I have hope, \add if\add* I should have a husband also to night, and should also bear sons;

would ye tarry for them till they were grown? would ye stay for them from having husbands? nay, my daughters; for it grieveth me much for your sakes that the hand of the \sc Lord\sc* is gone out against me.
And they lift up their voice, and wept again: and Orpah kissed her mother in law; but Ruth clave unto her.
And she said, Behold, thy sister in law is gone back unto her people, and unto her gods: return thou after thy sister in law.

And Ruth said, Intreat me not to leave thee, \add or\add* to return from following after thee: for whither thou goest, I will go; and where thou lodgest, I will lodge: thy people \add shall be\add* my people, and thy God my God:
where thou diest, will I die, and there will I be buried: the \sc Lord\sc* do so to me, and more also, \add if ought\add* but death part thee and me.
When she saw that she \add was\add* stedfastly minded to go with her, then she left speaking unto her.

So they two went until they came \add to\add* Beth-lehem. And it came to pass, when they were come \add to\add* Beth-lehem, that all the city was moved about them, and they said, \add Is\add* this Naomi?
And she said unto them, Call me not Naomi, call me Mara: for the Almighty hath dealt very bitterly with me.

I went out full, and the \sc Lord\sc* hath brought me \add home\add* again empty: why \add then\add* call ye me Naomi, seeing the \sc Lord\sc* hath testified against me, and the Almighty hath afflicted me?
So Naomi returned, and Ruth the Moabitess, her daughter in law, with her, which returned out of the country of Moab: and they came \add to\add* Beth-lehem in the beginning of barley harvest.
